text:
Keep an eye on the night sky in Octoberâ€”you might catch a falling star!

The Orionid meteor shower reaches its peak on the night of Oct. 21-22, with a new moon providing ideal skywatching conditions. The Draconids will also be visible earlier in the month. 

Here's what else to watch out for!

text:
Last week, we announced our new class of astronaut candidates: 10 pilots, scientists, doctors, and explorers from across the United States. 

They're starting two years of intensive training, after which they'll be eligible for missions to low Earth orbit, the Moon, and beyond. Come join the journey with usâ€”follow our new candidates on social media: https://go.nasa.gov/4mLeL7j

text:
Earlier this week, we announced our newest class of astronaut candidates â€” and you may have already seen their bios and read their stories. But do you know what book they would take with them to a desert island?

Get up-close and personal with our future explorers in today's episode of Houston, We Have A Podcast: go.nasa.gov/46D66h5

text:
Sept. 22 is the autumnal equinox in the Northern Hemisphere. On this day, our planet isn't tilted toward or away from the Sun, and both day and night are almost exactly 12 hours (with a few small exceptions).
 
How will you celebrate the start of fall?
comments_list:

We'll tie the night off by meandering the festival before getting rounded up and slain by some passing Catholics ğŸ‘", "author_name": "", "created_time": "2025-09-23T22:04:16.000Z", "likes_count": 0, "replies_count": 0}, {"comment_id": "Y29tbWVudDoxMzQwOTU4ODM3Mzk5NDg5XzEzNzM2MTMwNTQxODI3NjM=", "text": "I donâ€™t celebrate any of the four seasons. I always welcome Spring. Summer means the relentless hot, humid weather in Kansas; Fall offers a welcome relief from the summer heat and the beautiful changing of the foliage. Winterâ€¦ itâ€™s hard for me to find descriptive words. Cold, comes to mind. Freezing cold on too many days! 
Waaayy back in the day, we had lots of snow. We built traditional snowmen, of course. And then came the snow forts and snowball fights. When that grew boring, we waxed up the runners on our sleds and challenged each other on the distance we could travel down the hill.

text:
Hey kidâ€¦ wanna see a conjunction?
 
Before dawn on Sept. 19, you can! Nestled up to the crescent moon, you can find Venus and Regulus, one of the brightest nighttime stars. These three form a conjunction, meaning they appear near each other despite being far apart in space.

text:
Meet our new class of future astronauts!

On Monday, Sept. 22, we're introducing our 2025 class of astronaut candidates, selected from over 8,000 applications. Tune in at 12:30 p.m. EDT (1630 UTC) for the reveal: https://youtu.be/frX3-5xuGQs

Afterwards, they'll be taking your questions in a Reddit AMA ("Ask Me Anything") on the r/nasa Reddit community. Send in your questions anytime Monday afternoon, and our newly-announced explorers will be on to respond at 5:30 p.m. EDT (2130 UTC): https://www.reddit.com/r/nasa/

Our astronaut candidates will undergo two years of training before graduating as flight-eligible astronauts for missions to low Earth orbit, the Moon, and ultimately Mars. Ad astra!

text:
It's a bird! It's a plane! ...It's a super-jet! ğŸ¦¸

NASA's James Webb Space Telescope captured this blowtorch of seething gases erupting from a volcanically growing monster star. Stretching across eight light-years, the length of the stellar eruption is approximately twice the distance between our Sun and our next-nearest stars in the Alpha Centauri system. The size and strength of this stellar jet are rare, according to researchers.

The jets from protostars we observe are mainly from low-mass stars, but the discovery of this particular jet offers evidence that protostellar jets must scale up with the mass of the star powering them: The more massive the stellar engine propelling the plasma, the larger the gusher's size.
 
Learn more: https://go.nasa.gov/41YvgFt
